moves.1. e4: This is my first annotated game, so I would be appreciative of any and all constructive criticism.
moves.1... c5: I've recently taken a liking to the Sicilian.
moves.2. a3: I haven't studied this line, and this move seems pointless to me.  Could someone give me a continuation?
moves.2... Nc6: Going on with my usual development scheme.
moves.3. Nc3 g6 4. Nf3 Bg7 5. Bb5 Nf6 6. Bxc6: ? Seems like a waste of time.  Better was probably 6.d4.
moves.6... bxc6: Capture towards the center and back up d5.
moves.7... d5 8. exd5: I might have waited before taking here.
moves.8... cxd5 9. d4 cxd4 10. Qxd4: Bringing the queen in line with the enemy bishop is never a good idea.
moves.10... O-O 11. Bg5: This, along with the loose queen, concedes the bishop pair to me.
moves.14. O-O-O: I pondered over an eventual Bh6, but realized it would probably never work.
moves.14... e5: Gives me more center control and space, while also unpinning my d-pawn next move.
moves.15. Qxd8 Rxd8 16. Ne4 f5 17. Nc5: The knight's pretty useless and constricted here.
moves.17... a5 18. Ng5: Both knights are now loose and become targets of tactical play.
moves.19... e4: This move does more than open the line for the bishop to attack c3...
moves.20. g4: ?? Mandatory was 20.h4, giving the knight a retreat square.
moves.21. Ngxe4 fxe4 22. Nxe4 Rc6: Adding a third attacker onto c3.
moves.23. Rd3 Ba6 24. Rf3: Notice how passive white's pieces are.
moves.24... Re8: Bringing my last piece into play.
moves.25. Re1: ?? This walks straight into a pin and drops the other knight.  The move that loses outright.
?? Again, blocking the rook's only retreat square.  The game is lost, but better lose a knight than a rook.
moves.30. Nc5 Bxf4+: My opponent must have missed the check that came with taking the rook here, but the game would be lost even if the king were on b1.  Good game, wcates.  I hope you all enjoyed.
